Hey Todd,

I've worked with CUDA, it does offer some great possibilities
fo=
r cheap computing power utilizing GPU. I did not use it for 
evaluations bu=
t for evaluating a CPPN many times in parallel for large
HyperNEAT networks=
. I was able to get 47x faster than a reference
C++ CPU implementation. It =
wasn't too difficult to plug in the
finished GPU CPPN evaluation code into =
Python either.

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Todd Owen" <jtoddowen@.=
..> wrote:
>
> Are there plans to support HyperNEAT in the Python version? =
 I'm much
> more comfortable with Python than C++.  With the new release of=

> HyperSharpNEAT 2.0 (http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html), there is a
>=
 substantial code base to draw from.
> 
> Also, I'd be interested to extend=
 NEAT Python with Parallel Python
> (http://www.parallelpython.com/) to all=
ow evaluations on multiple
> cores and machines.
> 
> I've never worked wit=
h GPUs, but nVidia's CUDA capabilities look
> promising.  PyStream (http://=
code.google.com/p/pystream/) isn't being
> supported anymore by Tech-X.  Th=
eir new GPUlib
> (http://www.txcorp.com/technologies/GPULib/index.php) supp=
orts
> multiple languages.  Again, this would be for evaluating fitness
> f=
unctions.  Any experience or thoughts here?
> 
> --Todd
>
